title: Anyone Remember when Riot Said:
body:
Back when Riot made changes to wards, putting a 3 stealth ward limit per person, they (Riot) specifically stated that they would keep an eye on this change and see what develops. The idea behind this change was to get the team as a whole to work together on vision.

Not once since then has Riot spoken of this change and the impact it has had if any.

Well, from what I can see, in 95% of games (or somehow just my games) ever since the change, no one person but the support has been warding..... still. The ability to get decent vision on the map was killed by this change because most players don't seem to realize vision wins games.

My point here is that I (and maybe others) would like Riot to finally respond on the subject. (Or maybe be directed to a page in which they have, in the event I somehow missed it.)

Thanks~

replies.body:
Overall we're pretty happy with the ward limit per person. There's a limit to how much vision we think's right for the game (FOW's there for a reason), so the limit per player's allowed us to offer vision in other ways. Trinkets in particular we're really happy with - they generate some interesting gameplay. It's also put supports in a much more interesting spot, where they're able to invest in items rather than being forced to sink anywhere near as much money into vision.

Something that is a bit of barrier to appropriate trinket use though for some players is that they're put off by the upgrade cost. We're planning to test removing the gold cost for the upgraded versions in the preseason as a result, find out if that has a good effect on the game. You should pretty much always be upgrading them as is, so it's a change that's got the potential to help players that aren't appreciating the vision system yet engage with it more. At the same time it would also free up a bit of gold for players that are buying the upgrades at present.

Trinkets are one of the best things that happened to LoL 'lately' and as a support main, I was really happy when they introduced them. Warding was never only a support thing and with a free trinket for everyone, people learnt to use vision to their advantage.
But as a support, I still rush Sightstone and change to Sweeper's as soon as possible to achive more vision for my team and deny said vision to the enemy team (to prepare for ganks, etc).
I prefer Sightstone over Warding Totem since I can instantly place three wards instead of one (or three at level 9 with a 60 seconds cd after each charge). But besides the wards, Sightstone is a rather useless item to me and feels more like wasting an item slot, especially if you can have a Greater Stealth Totem for free.
Sure, your build is all about decisions and finding the best item for what you want to achieve but at this point, chosing between Sightstone and Warding Totem is more about personal preferences than real value.
I also know that Riot doesn't want to offer upgrades to the Sightstone because they don't want to force supports or junglers to buy this item but I personally do not feel forced to buy it. I just want to buy it - to help my team as much as possible. But I also want it to not feel like a huge sacrifice for supports...

**TL;DR:** Sightstone is one of the few items supports can choose from to actively aid their team (besides tier 3 gold income items, Locket or Mikael's, ...) compared to all the damage items that exist for carries and it feels weak next to a free Warding Totem.

I have mixed feelings about the idea of free upgrades. Many players don't upgrade their trinkets because they just spent all their gold on more damage or simply forget about it and noone farms 250 gold and recalls again just to buy an upgrade. Free upgrades definitely would make those items more popular. Maybe even if they'd only be free for the time of the preseason.
On the other hand, I'm not sure if it's healthy to offer free counterplay against invisible champions and traps once people reach level 9. Sure, we used to have Oracle's Elixir and still have pink wards for only 100 gold, but both needed to be bought and the ward uses one item slot.
Plus, offering a free Greater Vision Totem is like removing the gold cost from pink wards. Players could (and I'm sure a lot would) upgrade their yellow trinket for free, place a pink ward and then swap it for the red or blue trinket.

> noone farms 250 gold and recalls again just to buy an upgrade

I beg to differ, especially vs teams with stealth I will always go get that pink ward, multiple times farming just enough and recalling as soon as I can upgrade.
By noone I didn't mean literally noone but about 95% of players in my elo who still think warding/vision in general is a support's job.

Funny thing when I support and have an upgraded yellow trinket then people tell me to get a sightstone or complain "omg no vision". Then I ping the 3 wards I have placed down and it takes soooooo long to coax them to get them to upgrade their trinket. Some players may not deserve the benefits of this cheap vision but it's my team that suffers :( Also since yellow trinket is really good right now and I end up skipping sightstone sometimes.

I'm sorry Meddler, but I'm kind of against removing the gold cost of upgraded trinkets.

For one, vision costs money. This has always been the case. Wards, sightstone, pinks, etc. It's a lot of power in the right hands and there's always been a cost to it. 

But... I feel like it would have to be rebalanced. It doesn't really feel fair, to be honest. Early game, supports are expected to sink 800 gold, usually on their first buy, for vision. 250 gold on everyone else shouldn't feel like much in comparison, especially for the perks trinket upgrades have over sightstone. Four wards every recall vs recharging wards with a two limit feels... if one of those are free, it really feels like it's devaluing the previous. If made free in their current state, something would have to change or there would need to be changes for sightstone.

You should just remove the cost of items completely because you should pretty much always be buying items. You generally make really good logical posts. The reasoning here is pretty horrible though. 

**The whole point** of having items you can buy is so that you CHOOSE to buy the item you think will be of the most value at certain points. That's like you saying 'well Ahri should always buy ludens so lets make it free'. 
_
(Disclaimer: I'm not against these changes I'm actually for them just the reason you gave don't make sense.)_

The logic here is that Vision does not give you any direct combat stats like Ludens Echo or Infinity Edge. Vision helps you with fighting in a way that you can make better decision based on what you see on the map.

Yeah I get that, but why shouldn't you have to pay for that advantage? Why just give it to everyone for free if they can't see the value of it themselves? It's essentially the same as forcing people to buy certain items because they're the best and they're not good enough to see the value of the item? 

They already forced you to get 1 free ward because bad players never ever brought wards. Counter warding is already the most boring unengaged part of the game, running around everywhere scanning for wards.

Personally I think they should lower the cap to 1 or 2 wards per person but reduce the cd of how fast trinkets refresh. You'll see a lot more ganks and fights when you can't see the entire map the whole game because there's constantly 15 wards on the map.

It would make me feel better when my carries are getting caught out and complain about vision problems. I always have to ping on the map that i have the maximum of placeable wards placed and that its not my fault that we lack vision. Who gets blamed? The support. 

This is also one of the reasons why i hope that more junglers follow the example of GV Move and buy a sightstone.

I have to agree with you here, the upgrades shouldn't be free, however I do wonder if removing the cost for a time in preseason could actually tempt enough of the playerbase to in fact try them out will in turn increase their appreciation of the upgrades, so then even with the cost reimplemented, a lot of players would still go for it.
TL;DR Removal of upgrade cost could create better habits in the long run

Even free, you'd still have a choice to do: upgrading the yellow trinket to green or pink wards? swap to red or blue trinket?

The decision making is still there. Putting those upgrades free would help other people than the support to work on vision, as OP required. It could also reduce a little the factor in low elo "I'm behind I won't put money in vision" and "I'm ahead I can afford it" putting the team behind even further behind. I don't say it's a valid way of thinking, but at low elo it is exactly what I see. Silver players will never buy the upgrade if behind, while they would sometimes while ahead, creating even more pick situation.

You make some good points about how its a little snowbally, but the same thing still applies to all other items. Just because low elo players are not making good choices and buying the items they need doesn't _necessarily_ mean rito should force it down their throats by making it so they HAVE to purchase the right items.  

It's like when the entire enemy team is AP and your team builds ninja tabi. Is riot going to make it so you don't get a choice of boots instead it automatically chooses which boots are best and gives you them? Item costs and choices are a huge part of what makes up this game.

I think the real problem is that people dont invest in warding because it's boring. Counter warding and warding is one of the least fun things you can do in a game. It occasionally creates interesting situations when you're fighting over a ward. But _making wards more scarce_ will increase the importance of protecting wards causing people to be more likely to defend them. As well as create more opportunities for ganks and such.
**
tldr; 
rather than force everyone to ward heaps because thats what the pros do, when its obviously a boring and unfun aspect of league hence noone does it, why not make it so pros can't ward as much?**

By your icon, I can tell you remember the olden days where we Support mains bought 9 wards at a time. You likely also saw the olden days where pro Support mains had as many as 27 wards on them (to leave inventory space for basic boots, HoG, and Philo Stone).

You want Riot to make pros ward even less now? And does your proposed solution also apply to the mere mortals too? One giant draw for pro play (at least for me) is that they play the exact same game with the exact same rules and pieces as I do, albeit a couple patches behind. Breaking that parity would be a giant mistake, imo. Also what makes you think the vision game isn't fun? Sure it's not gonna get an announcement and giant banner in-game (PENTA-WARD-KILL!) and it probably won't be featured in Random LoL Moments or Top 5 Plays, but it is an interesting and necessary part of the game.

That aside, using Luden's and Ninja Tabi as extensions of this proposal is really comparing apples to oranges. Eh...actually they're not TOTALLY different as they're both in the item system, I suppose, so navel oranges to {{champion:41}}'s blood oranges. Obviously they're not going to make those high ticket items free, but trinkets occupy a unique niche in that they're additionally gated by level and have absolutely no reason to be passed up at the first possible chance--unlike Elixirs that are mostly wasted if you can't make the most of them during their window or jungle upgrades (do I get this {{item:3134}} for Warrior enchant or do I build it into {{item:3142}} instead?).

That said, I was afraid Riot might eventually go the spoon-feeding route and remove the cost of trinket upgrades. The people that are too cheap or forgetful to upgrade it don't deserve the massive power spike they give.

That said I agree with you you're right, the gold cost is relatively small and for the most part there's not really much point it existing. It only really serves as a barrier for noobs. But in a way that's good because noobs don't understand the value of vision _and counter vision_ so it balances out. Because you have less people warding, but less people clearing wards. If you want more people to have upgraded trinkets, it'd be easier to automatically give it to them.

> [{quoted}](name=Meddler,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=tl8Arxck,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2015-07-16T08:33:15.011+0000)
>
>  It's also put supports in a much more interesting spot, where they're able to invest in items rather than being forced to sink anywhere near as much money into vision.

I love to hear this from a Rioter.  What I'd love even more is if you take this to the logical extreme and completely remove the "opportunity" to trash your personal gold to provide more vision for the team.  Trinkets allow vision to be limited by resources built into the trinket system: time, charges, the trinket slot.  Not only does that not need to interact with the gold and stat-item slots, it's actually better if it doesn't.  Gold is an individual resource.  Spending it for diffuse teamwide benefits has strong balance implications.

Because it can never be a genuine choice to have vision or stats.  The team needs vision, but it also needs some people to have strong stats.  So weakening yourself with vision items (either Sightstone or consumable) is a poison pill that *someone* has to take so that *someone else* can win fights.  And then it turns people off the role that gets stuck with that burden.  Or they just reject it and throw, and everyone has a bad time.

A word like "selfish" shouldn't even be able to apply to how you spend your gold; the normal expectation should be that you're spending it to become the best (insert champion name) you can be, to become better at doing the things that champion does.  This should be no less true for peel and heals/shields and magical journeys and eating your friends than it is for dealing tons of damage.

The competition (maybe you'd prefer if I don't name names) is already proving that allowing supports to be full champions with a similar power level to any other doesn't ruin a MOBA.  I wish a support was allowed to be powerful in this game too.

As if that wasn't ambitious enough already, I'd also like to see more vision options than just wards or nothing.  Blue trinket hasn't really caught on, probably because the uptime ratio is so terrible compared to leaving a lasting ward; but what if it had a significantly shorter cooldown in exchange for having nearly no duration?  (Or, for that matter, what if it lasted for 10 seconds of vision that you couldn't negate by any means other than leaving the area?)  What if anyone could spend a trinket slot to get (a watered down version of) Quinn, Kallista or even Ashe's vision abilities?  What if Twin Shadows was a trinket instead of an item with unimpressive stats, would it see more use if you could get the active a la carte?

The current trinkets seem like they might have been intended to be a sort of rock, paper, scissors of vision that never really developed (scrying orb can't be swept, but also can't sweep regular wards and is worse than regular wards if they are not frequently swept).  Can you find a way to add Spock and a lizard?

I feel that the biggest issue with the upgrade is that people don't know the value of vision. People who were warding a lot before the reduction in upgrade price were the first to embrace the upgrade price reduction and fall in love with it (like I have).

But I still commonly run into players who place <6 wards in an entire game and spend that entire game with the starting yellow trinket, some who even place an average of ~2. And I'm including ranked games, and not just all bronze ones. Those people might upgrade their trinket at their first back after lvl 9 if it's free, but that doesn't mean they'll actually use it more.

The average player in League is vastly under warding right now and probably always has been. Personally I under ward almost every single game. I especially don't buy early greens often enough. Despite that I am almost always the top warder on either team (if you exclude people with sightstones when I don't have one).

What players need is a way to learn the value of vision. Vision shouldn't be a thing you almost completely ignore as a new player until you've been playing for days or maybe even weeks. Introduce it in the starter tutorial and make it at least a little relevant, including vs early bots. Right now if you play against intermediate bots the bot 'support' buys a sightstone, almost every bot buys a green ward, and yet none of them ward things. Those items just sit in their inventory useless. A simple 'if safe, ward these certain spots with trinket/sightstone' addition to their AI would be a great start.

Of course what people really need is a bit more than that. They need clearer ways to understand the value of vision in their regular games vs players. They need better post game metrics related to vision (and they should be accessible without opening a web browser). Partly they could use some community involvement like user made tutorials on warding and sweeping wards.

You can't force a horse to drink the water. But you can tell them why they're dieing of dehydration and how to fix it. :p

I would love to see more combat stats from the Ruby Sightstone - that would be healthier for the vision game, since even junglers (at higher levels of play) are building it now.  

Otherwise, I'm quite happy that the burden of warding has been balanced across the team.  I main support and I remember how useless it felt supporting in Season 3.  I like what you guys have done with vision.  Item balance, however, is another issue.  =]
Problem is: If you give the Sightstone too good stats, everyone's gonna buy one and more than two Sightstone grant way too much vision..

You don't give it OP stats, just something better than its current state.  Maybe add some mana onto it or allow the wards to regenerate while in the battlefield.  And you can't make use of multiple sightstones due to the ward cap.

Not really. the three wards per player cap is there for a reason - it's as much vision as Riot finds acceptable. All Sightstone does is reliably let you hit that cap. There's no reason even five Sightstones should lead to over the top ward coverage.

Well, with five people placing three wards, you can have vision on about 50% of all bushes on Summoner's Rift which is okay. But the problem with Sightstone is that you can instantly place three wards whereas the Greater Stealth Totem has 60s cooldown between two charges. You can successfully prevent most ganks with that... Powerful stats and granting that much vision is kind of imbalanced.

When people ask for combat stats on Sightstone they're not asking for a 2500 gold item with 80 AP and 15 magic pen or whatever, they basically just mean an alternative to Ruby Sightstone (similar price) that instead of giving a flat amount of health, gives a smaller amount of health and a more relevant stat like AP or AD. It would still be a horrendously slot inefficient item regarding combat stats, with essentially no reason for a carry to take it over Greater Stealth Totem, it'd just feel better on supports and junglers.
